overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnic, amend and establish various definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, and incorporate fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [12] The measure establishes heightened penalties if another person suffers substantial bodily injury, serious bodily injury, or death as a result of the fireworks offenses. [12] The fireworks infractions system will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases, while also allowing them to prioritize higher-level cases as appropriate. [12]
appropriations: The Conference Committee has amended this measure by deleting the appropriation. [13] A previous version of the measure was to appropriate funds, but this has been removed. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided legislative documents do not contain specific assumptions or a methodology for calculating financial projections. [12] The fiscal impact is derived from the establishment of new fines, fees, and penalties detailed within the bill. [12]
agency_impact: The fireworks infractions system will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases. [12] The judiciary will need to incorporate fireworks infractions into the adjudication process currently used for traffic and emergency period infractions, which will allow the judiciary to reserve resources for cases that require more resources. [12] Additionally, any person who ships fireworks into the State must notify the state fire marshal regarding shipment details. [12]
economic_impact: The measure establishes a $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for violating consumer fireworks prohibitions and a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for certain unlawful distributions. [12] [12] For carriers, a first offense is subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine, a second offense is subject to a $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine, and a third or subsequent offense is subject to a $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] [12] [12] Other violations of the chapter are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt). [12]
policy_impact: This Act incorporates fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions under chapter 291D, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [12] The measure establishes various new criminal offenses, ranging from petty misdemeanors to class A felonies, particularly for offenses that result in substantial bodily injury, serious bodily injury, or death to another person. [12] [12] The bill also amends multiple definitions related to fireworks to provide greater clarity and enforcement capability. [12]
revenue_sources: Revenue from fines will be collected by the court, with twenty per cent paid to the State and eighty per cent to the county in which the fine was imposed. [12] Permit fees are established, including a fee of $25 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for consumer fireworks and a fee of $110 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for aerial devices or display fireworks. [12] [12] Additionally, the court shall impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction, which will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [12]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The fiscal implications of this measure are ongoing and result from the establishment of new fines and fees. [12] Any person who violates certain consumer fireworks prohibitions shall be subject to a $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine, while another violation is subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] [12] For carriers shipping fireworks, a first offense is subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] A second offense committed within five years is subject to a $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] A third or subsequent offense committed within five years is subject to a $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] Permit fees include $25 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for firecrackers and cultural uses, and $110 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for aerial devices or display fireworks. [12] [12] Other general violations are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt). [12] The court will also impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction in which judgment is entered in favor of the State. [12] Of the fines collected, eighty per cent will go to the county and twenty per cent to the State. [12] These revenue streams are permanent, though the total amount to be collected annually is indeterminate. [12]
operating_revenue_impact: The State is projected to receive twenty per cent of all fines collected for violations of this chapter. [12] Counties will receive eighty per cent of collected fines, which must be expended for law enforcement purposes. [12] The judiciary will receive revenue from a new administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction, which will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [12]

fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The fiscal framework established by this Act is permanent, so the fiscal implications after six years are expected to be consistent with the initial years of implementation. [12] The system of fines and fees, along with the associated revenue distribution and administrative costs for the judiciary, will continue. [12] The revenue generated from ongoing enforcement will persist as long as the law is in effect. [12]

reports_required: Health care facilities in the State are required to report all incidents of serious injuries and fatalities caused by fireworks to the department of health and the police department of the county in which the person was treated. [12] Any person shipping fireworks into the State or interisland must notify the appropriate county and state law enforcement agencies. [12] Additionally, importers must notify the state fire marshal in writing of an expected shipment's landing date. [12]
